Literature Review: Tobamoviruses, a genus of plant viruses, have long been a significant threat to global agriculture, causing substantial economic losses in various crops. The recent emergence of new tobamovirus species, such as the tomato brown rugose fruit virus (ToBRFV), has further intensified concerns about their impact on food security. This literature review aims to explore the complex interactions between tobamoviruses and plant immunity, highlighting the ongoing evolutionary arms race between these pathogens and their hosts.Plant immunity against tobamoviruses involves a sophisticated multilayered defense system. The first line of defense is pattern-triggered immunity (PTI), which recognizes conserved molecular patterns associated with pathogens. Nicotiana benthamiana plants, for instance, can detect the coat protein (CP) of the tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) through the receptor-like kinase BAK1, triggering PTI responses (Niehl et al., 2016). This recognition initiates a cascade of defense responses, including the production of reactive oxygen species and the activation of defense-related genes.A critical component of plant immunity against tobamoviruses is RNA silencing, a sequence-specific antiviral mechanism. Plants employ small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) to target and degrade viral RNA, effectively limiting virus replication and spread. The importance of RNA silencing in tobamovirus resistance is underscored by the fact that many tobamoviruses encode suppressors of RNA silencing, such as the 126K protein of TMV (Wang et al., 2012). These viral suppressors interfere with various steps of the silencing pathway, allowing the virus to evade this host defense mechanism.Another crucial aspect of plant immunity against tobamoviruses is the activation of resistance (R) genes. These genes encode proteins that recognize specific viral effectors, triggering a robust immune response known as effector-triggered immunity (ETI). The classic example is the N gene in tobacco, which confers resistance to TMV by recognizing the viral replicase protein (Padmanabhan et al., 2013). ETI often leads to a hypersensitive response (HR), characterized by localized cell death that restricts virus spread.Phytohormones play a vital role in orchestrating plant defense responses against tobamoviruses. Salicylic acid (SA) is particularly important in mediating resistance to these viruses. SA accumulation is associated with the activation of systemic acquired resistance (SAR), a broad-spectrum defense mechanism that protects uninfected parts of the plant against subsequent infections. The NPR1 protein, a key regulator of SA-mediated immunity, has been shown to be crucial for resistance against TMV in Arabidopsis (Zhu et al., 2011).Despite these sophisticated defense mechanisms, tobamoviruses have evolved various strategies to counteract plant immunity. For instance, the TMV replicase protein not only suppresses RNA silencing but also interferes with SA-mediated defenses by interacting with the host protein ATF2, a transcriptional activator of defense genes (Wang et al., 2009). This multifaceted approach allows the virus to simultaneously target different aspects of the plant immune system.The emergence of ToBRFV has highlighted the ongoing evolution of tobamoviruses and their ability to overcome existing resistance mechanisms. ToBRFV can infect tomato varieties carrying the Tm-22 resistance gene, which has been effective against other tobamoviruses for decades (Luria et al., 2017). This breakthrough emphasizes the need for a deeper understanding of the molecular interactions between tobamoviruses and plant immunity to develop durable resistance strategies.Recent research has explored novel approaches to enhance plant resistance against tobamoviruses. One promising strategy involves the use of CRISPR/Cas9 technology to engineer resistance. Kis et al. (2019) demonstrated that expressing CRISPR/Cas9 constructs targeting conserved regions of the TMV genome could confer resistance in Nicotiana benthamiana plants. This approach offers the potential for developing broad-spectrum resistance against multiple tobamovirus species.Another area of active research is the exploitation of natural resistance sources. Wild relatives of cultivated crops often harbor diverse resistance genes that can be introgressed into elite varieties. For example, Hak et al. (2020) identified a novel resistance gene, Tm-1β, from wild tomato species that confers resistance to ToBRFV. Such discoveries provide valuable resources for breeding programs aimed at developing resistant cultivars.Understanding the molecular basis of tobamovirus-plant interactions is crucial for developing effective control strategies. Recent advances in high-throughput sequencing and proteomics have enabled researchers to gain deeper insights into the global changes in gene expression and protein abundance during tobamovirus infection. These studies have revealed complex networks of host factors that are manipulated by the virus to promote its replication and movement (Zhao et al., 2019).In conclusion, the perpetual interplay between tobamoviruses and plant immunity represents a fascinating example of co-evolution between pathogens and their hosts. As new tobamovirus species continue to emerge and overcome existing resistance mechanisms, there is an urgent need for innovative approaches to crop protection. By leveraging our growing understanding of plant-virus interactions and employing cutting-edge technologies, researchers can develop more durable and broad-spectrum resistance strategies to safeguard global food security in the face of evolving tobamovirus threats.
